importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, establishing himself as a top young talent in international chess.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The span from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky’s rise from youth champion to global chess influencer, highlighting a period of sustained excellence and public engagement in chess education and livestreaming.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He was born and raised in the San Francisco Bay Area and earned grandmaster status before high school.
Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, becoming the youngest player to claim the California K-12 Championship that same year.
He earned a bachelor’s degree in history from Stanford University in 2019.
He authored a chess manual at age 14 and became a regular contributor to Chess Life and a chess columnist for the New York Times.
He built a massive online following with nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers.
He was widely recognized for livestreaming chess games and teaching complex strategies in an accessible way, making chess engaging for beginners and enthusiasts alike.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, confirmed his death and described him as a talented player, commentator, educator, and beloved community member.
The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his passing, citing his impact on chess education and global community engagement.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at 29, leaving behind a legacy as a gifted player, educator, and online chess influencer. He earned grandmaster status before high school, won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, and became a prominent chess columnist for the New York Times. Through his extensive online presence—nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers—he made chess accessible and engaging for millions. As head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center, he inspired countless players, and his passing was mourned by the International Chess Federation, Saint Louis Chess Club, and the broader chess world, with the 2025 US Chess Championship beginning with a moment of silence in his honor.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
